data.title: Many Faces of Payne County
data.text:
Many Faces of Payne County - Page 1

The Many Faces of Payne County

Page 1 Page 2

A familiar face (and voice) in Stillwaters business district for half a century was Forrest Boaz, on the right, in his first establishment at Sixth and Main streets on the site later occupied by the Grand Hotel and the Stillwater National Bank. Bozie specialized first in saddles and harnesses and was later known for his craftsmanship in canvas work and car upholstery until his death in 1968. He was a founder of both state and Stillwater American Legion organizations. The car has a 1927 tag. Photo courtesy of Forrest K. Boaz.

Joshua B. Brock, front row center, built the Citizens Bank of 1894. He made the 1889 Land Run, settling southeast of Stillwater. He specialized in stone masonry. Two of his crew members are holding hods, used then to carry concrete, including up ladders. Brock was known for his tobacco-chewing horse. Often he bit off a chew of tobacco and then broke off another for his horse. They both chewed as they looked over the job. Brocks descendants still live on the homestead. Photo courtesy of Kirby Brock. Note: Joshua was the son of Holland Lockwood and Letitia (House) Brock. His family are buried in Fairlawn Cemetery, Stillwater, Payne Co., Ok.

This photo was taken in 1904. It shows Powhattan B. Molloy in a four generation picture. Although they spent some of their life in Payne Co., OK, Powhatten and his wife, Mary are buried in Oakdale Cemetery, Agra, Lincoln Co., OK.

Lavinia Caroline (Hurt) McKnight, born August 4, 1870; died April 1920. Charles Franklin McKnight, born August 20, 1859; died 1939. They were the parents of Jessie (McKnight) Prickett Taylor. Original picture was made in 1897. Charles and Lavinia, Martha (2nd wife of Charles), Rebecca (mother of Charles), and an infant are all buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK.

A picture of Georgia McKnight in 1945.

This log cabin was the first house built by Francis Barclay Eaton on his claim of 1891, south of Ripley. Pictured are Francis Barclay Eaton, Francis Victor and Walter Eaton on horse, May Leabo Eaton and daughter, June, age 4 months. Francis Barclay Eaton fought in the Civil War. Both he, and his wife, Rachel Ellen (Ward) Eaton, are buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK.

William and Mary Topper with sons Charles and Lee taken in 1916. Will and Mary are buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK.

Edna (Eaton) Wilson taken in 1980.

Will and Mattie Colson

A wedding picture of Oren Kessler and Lettie Gertrude May (Hesser) Gillespie taken in 1915. Kessler or "OK" as he was called was born on May 22, 1896 to George T. and Bettie Ann (Harding) Gillespie. He died on November 21, 1939. Lettie was born on May 29, 1899 to John Wesley and May (Knittle) Hesser. Both are buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK.

Brothers Francis and Kessler Gillespie pose for the second picture.

A picture of Sarah Jane (Taylor) Reed taken on July 4, 1926. Sarah Jane was born in 1847 and died in 1933. She was the wife of Orange A. Reed. He was born in 1838 and died in 1913. Both are buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK.

Pictured are Hubbard and Lida (McCray) Hammock with sons Pete, Charles and John. Hubbard's parents were Hubbard's parents were Samuel and Teresa (Qualls) Hammock. Lida was Hubbard's first wife. After Lida died, he married Almarinda "Rinda" (Ellis) Bealer Hammock on December 9, 1896. Hubbard, Lida, Charles and John are buried in Mt. Hope Cemetery which is near Mehan/Ripley Oklahoma.

Hubbard A. and Lida Margaret (McCray) Hammocks homestead.

George Washington and Cora (Ballard) Flint.

George and Edna (Flower) Brake.

Pictured are Albert and Carrie belle (Myrick) Cooper and son Audra and daughter Louisa, taken in 1946.

Pictured are Martha Helton, Eunice McFarland and Patti Dunlap. Later they were Martha Norton, Eunice Quimby, and Patti Carr.

Ralph and Goldie Stiles taken on their wedding day in 1934.

Ralph's obituary as published in the Stillwater NewsPress

Ralph Garland Stiles

(November 23, 1912 - May 6, 2009)

Ralph Garland Stiles a longtime Ripley resident went to be with his Lord and Savior on Wednesday, May 06, 2009 at the age of 96. Funeral services are scheduled for 10:00 a.m., Friday at the Mehan Union Church with interment to follow at the Mt. Hope Cemetery, Ripley. Pastor Larry Eslinger will officiate. Arrangements are entrusted to Palmer Marler Funeral Home, Cushing, Oklahoma. Ralph was born on November 23, 1912 in Golden, Missouri to the late William Bradley and Ida Dora (Hill) Stiles. He grew up in Cassville, where he attended school. Ralph married Goldie Jones on April 6, 1934 in Eureka Springs, AR. He worked as a carpenter for Jack Shelton and Harry Sneed, just to name a few. After moving back to Ripley in 1963, their home has been a pillar of the community. During the last 45 years in Ripley, Ralph and Goldie have spent much of their time spreading the word of God. Throughout their lives Ralph has built and Goldie pastored numerous churches. They continue to grace the lives of so many to this day with their teaching and inspiration. Ralph made bread boxes and canister sets for many of the family. He enjoyed fishing and solving puzzles. Their marriage of 75 years had such a special bond that everytime a family member said I love you, Ralph would replyWe love you, too. Ralph is survived by his wife Goldie of the home, son Alfred Stiles and wife Pat of Yale, daughters Novella Lineberry of Albuquerque, NM, Leota Shay of Ripley and Leona Stiles of Ripley, 11 grandchildren, 26 great grandchildren and 20 great great grandchildren, and numerous nieces and nephews. He was preceded in death by his parents, his four brothers and his sister.

In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Diamond Valley Church, C/O Palmer Marler Funeral Home, P.O. Box 710, Cushing, OK 74023.

Cyrus Needham Van Pelt was born in 1851. He married Bettie (Boston) VanPelt. He had worked as the Assistant Editor of "The Farmer" newspaper in Missouri. After his wife died, he moved to Oklahoma. Cyrus became the editor and owner of "The Ripley Record" for a while. He died in 1929 and is buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne Co., OK. He shares a headstonewith his daughter, Marie.

Marie (Van Pelt) Mitchell. Marie was born to C.N. and Bettie (Boston) Van Pelt in 1881. She was a concert pianist and played with the Otto Gray Band. She contracted whooping cough and died in 1928. Her son, Alvan, went on to become a very famous author and a well known man in the United States Air Force.

Cyrus Newton Van Pelt and daughter Marie Mitchell pose in this potograph.

In 1924, George Youngblood, a Ripley business man and Frank Sherrill, a fiddler and oil worker, put together the first band. As it attracted attention they brought in as a front man colorful Billy McGinty, a former Teddy Roosevelt Rough Rider and performer with Buffalo Bill. Their group became the Billy McGinty's Cowboy Band. Wne the demands for performances became too great, McGinty and the others turned the band over to Otto Gray. He reorganized, added new personnel, and achieved national fame. Band members are, front row, left to right, Marie Mitchell, an unidentified child, Mrs. Billy (Mollie) McGinty, Billy McGinty, Paul Sharum and Ulys Moore. In the back row are Harry Hackney, Frank Sherrill, Roy Munday, Guy Messecar, and Paul Harrison. Seated in the front is Ernest Bevins. Photo Courtesy of Marie Sherrill Rainwater.

Otto Gray's band consisted largely of this group; left to right, Ernest Bevins, Lee Allen, Chief Sanders, Wade (Hy) Allen, Owen Gray (Otto's son) Florence Powell Gray (Otto's wife), who was always called "Mommie," Otto, and Rex, who was billed as "The Wonderful Police Dog," and the "bark of the air." Rex barked to the rythm of the music during radio shows. Photo courtesy of Mrs. Jim (Ruth) Wells.

This photo came from Penny (Spicer) Churchill. It is a photo of James Edward Spicer and his wife Effie May (Ballard) Spicer. Their children are with them (left to right) Veda, Verda Hazel, Vernon and Vernal Spicer. Jamesand Effieand Vernon are all buried in Ripley Oak Park Cemetery in Ripley, Oklahoma.

More photos on page 2. See the link at the top of the page.

******************************************************

Please check out all the work that I have done on FindAGrave.com. I've been working diligently to get as many headstone photos, family history information and family photos onto as many memorials as I can.

Pammy In Oklahoma

Ripley Oak Park Cemetery, Ripley, Payne, Oklahoma, USA

Mt. Hope Cemetery, Mehan/Ripley area

If you like what you see or would like to add any information to these pictures or would like to share your own pictures: Please feel free to e-mail me at [email protected].
